column2: The Two-Leaved Pine
column3: The Two Leaved Pine

column2: The Two-Leaved Pine (Pinus contorta, var.
column3: The Two Leaved Pine (Pinus contorta, v a r.

column2: Murrayana), above the Silver Fir zone, forms the bulk of the alpine forests up to a height of from 8000 to 9500 feet above the sea, growing in beautiful order on moraines scarcely changed as yet by post-glacial weathering.
column3: Murrayana), above the Silver Fir zone, forms the bulk of the alpine forests up to a height of from eight thousand to nine thousand five hundred feet above the sea, growing in beautiful order on moraines scarcely changed as yet by post glacial weathering.

column2: Compared with the giants of the lower regions this is a small tree, seldom exceeding a height of eighty or ninety feet.
column3: Compared with the giants of the lower regions this is a small tree, seldom exceeding a height of eighty or ninety feet.

column2: The largest I ever measured was ninety feet high and a little over six feet in diameter.
column3: The largest I ever measured was ninety feet high and a little over six feet in diameter.

column2: The average height of mature trees throughout the entire belt is probably not far from fifty or sixty feet with a diameter of two feet.
column3: The average height of mature trees throughout the entire belt is probably not far from fifty or sixty feet with a diameter of two feet.

column2: It is a well-proportioned, rather handsome tree with grayish-brown bark and crooked, much-divided branches which cover the greater part of the trunk, but not so densely as to prevent it being seen.
column3: It is a well proportioned, rather handsome tree with grayish brown bark and crooked, much divided branches which cover the greater part of the trunk, but not so densely as to prevent it being seen.

column2: The lower limbs, like those of most other conifers that grow in snowy regions, curve downward, gradually take a horizontal position about half-way up the trunk, then aspire more and more toward the summit.
column3: The lower limbs, like those of most other conifers that grow in snowy regions, curve downward, gradually take a horizontal position about half-way up the trunk, then aspire more and more toward the summit.

column2: The short, rigid needles in fascicles of two are arranged in comparatively long cylindrical tassels at the ends of the tough up-curving branches.
column3: The short, rigid needles in fascicles of two are arranged in comparatively long cylindrical tassels at the ends of the tough up curving branches.

column2: The cones are about two inches long, growing in clusters among the needles without any striking effect except while very young, when the flowers are of a vivid crimson color and the whole tree appears to be dotted with brilliant flowers.
column3: The cones are about two inches long, growing in clusters among the needles without any striking effect except while very young, when the flowers are of a vivid crimson color and the whole tree appears to be dotted with brilliant flowers.

column2: The staminate flowers are still more showy on account of their great abundance, often giving a reddish-yellow tinge to the whole mass of foliage and filling the air with pollen.
column3: The staminate flowers are still more showy on account of their great abundance, often giving a reddish yellow tinge to the whole mass of foliage and filling the air with pollen.

column2: No other pine on the Range is so regularly planted as this one, covering moraines that extend along the sides of the high rocky valleys for miles without interruption.
column3: No other pine on the Range is so regularly planted as this one, covering moraines that extend along the sides of the high rocky valleys for miles without interruption.

column2: The thin bark is streaked and sprinkled with resin as though it had been showered upon the forest like rain.
column3: The thin bark is streaked and sprinkled with resin as though it had been showered upon the forest like rain.

column2: Therefore this tree more than any other is subject to destruction by fire.
column3: Therefore this tree more than any other is subject to destruction by fire.

column2: During strong winds extensive forests are destroyed, the flames leaping from tree to tree in continuous belts that go surging and racing onward above the bending wood like prairie-grass fires.
column3: During strong winds extensive forests are destroyed, the flames leaping from tree to tree in continuous belts that go surging and racing onward above the bending wood like prairie grass fires.

column2: During the calm season of Indian summer the fire creeps quietly along the ground, feeding on the needles and cones; arriving at the foot of a tree, the resiny bark is ignited and the heated air ascends in a swift current, increasing in velocity and dragging the flames upward.
column3: During the calm season of Indian summer the fire creeps quietly along the ground, feeding on the needles and cones; arriving at the foot of a tree, the resiny bark is ignited and the heated air ascends in a swift current, increasing in velocity and dragging the flames upward.

column2: Then the leaves catch forming an immense column of fire, beautifully spired on the edges and tinted a rose-purple hue.
column3: Then the leaves catch forming an immense column of fire, beautifully spired on the edges and tinted a rose purple hue.

column2: It rushes aloft thirty or forty feet above the top of the tree, forming a grand spectacle, especially at night.
column3: It rushes aloft thirty or forty feet above the top of the tree, forming a grand spectacle, especially at night.

column2: It lasts, however, only a few seconds, vanishing with magical rapidity, to be succeeded by others along the fire-line at irregular intervals, tree after tree, upflashing and darting, leaving the trunks and branches scarcely scarred.
column3: It lasts, however, only a few seconds, vanishing with magical rapidity, to be succeeded by others along the fire line at irregular intervals, tree after tree, upflashing and darting, leaving the trunks and branches scarcely scarred.

column2: The heat, however, is sufficient to kill the tree and in a few years the bark shrivels and falls off.
column3: The heat, however, is sufficient to kill the tree and in a few years the bark shrivels and falls off.

column2: Forests miles in extent are thus killed and left standing, with the branches on, but peeled and rigid, appearing gray in the distance like misty clouds.
column3: Forests miles in extent are thus killed and left standing, with the branches on, but peeled and rigid, appearing gray in the distance like misty clouds.

column2: Later the branches drop off, leaving a forest of bleached spars.
column3: Later the branches drop off, leaving a forest of bleached spars.

column2: At length the roots decay and the forlorn gray trunks are blown down during some storm and piled one upon another, encumbering the ground until, dry and seasoned, they are consumed by another fire and leave the ground ready for a fresh crop.
column3: At length the roots decay and the forlorn gray trunks are blown down during some storm and piled one upon another, encumbering the ground until, dry and seasoned, they are consumed by another fire and leave the ground ready for a fresh crop.

column2: In sheltered lake-hollows, on beds of alluvium, this pine varies so far from the common form that frequently it could be taken for a distinct species, growing in damp sods like grasses from forty to eighty feet high, bending all together to the breeze and whirling in eddying gusts more lively than any other tree in the woods.
column3: In sheltered lake hollows, on beds of alluvium, this pine varies so far from the common form that frequently it could be taken for a distinct species, growing in damp sods like grasses from forty to eighty feet high, bending all together to the breeze and whirling in eddying gusts more lively than any other tree in the woods.

column2: I frequently found specimens fifty feet high less than five inches in diameter.
column3: I frequently found specimens fifty feet high less than five inches in diameter.

column2: Being so slender and at the same time clad with leafy boughs, it is often bent and weighed down to the ground when laden with soft snow; thus forming fine ornamental arches, many of them to last until the melting of the snow in the spring.
column3: Being so slender and at the same time clad with leafy boughs, it is often bent and weighed down to the ground when laden with soft snow; thus forming fine ornamental arches, many of them to last until the melting of the snow in the spring.

column2: The Mountain Pine
column3: The Mountain Pine

column2: The Mountain Pine (Pinus monticola) is the noblest tree of the alpine zone--hardy and long-lived towering grandly above its companions and becoming stronger and more imposing just where other species begin to crouch and disappear.
column3: The Mountain Pine (Pinus monticola) is the noblest tree of the alpine zone-hardy and long lived towering grandly above its companions and becoming stronger and more imposing just where other species begin to crouch and disappear.

column2: At its best it is usually about ninety feet high and five or six feet in diameter, though you may find specimens here and there considerably larger than this.
column3: At its best it is usually about ninety feet high and five or six feet in diameter, though you may find specimens here and there considerably larger than this.

column2: It is as massive and suggestive of enduring strength as an oak.
column3: It is as massive and suggestive of enduring strength as an oak.

column2: About two-thirds of the trunk is commonly free of limbs, but close, fringy tufts of spray occur nearly all the way down to the ground.
column3: About two thirds of the trunk is commonly free of limbs, but close, fringy tufts of spray occur nearly all the way down to the ground.

column2: On trees that occupy exposed situations near its upper limit the bark is deep reddish-brown and rather deeply furrowed, the main furrows running nearly parallel to each other and connected on the old trees by conspicuous cross-furrows.
column3: On trees that occupy exposed situations near its upper limit the bark is deep reddish brown and rather deeply furrowed, the main furrows running nearly parallel to each other and connected on the old trees by conspicuous cross furrows.

column2: The cones are from four to eight inches long, smooth, slender, cylindrical and somewhat curved. They grow in clusters of from three to six or seven and become pendulous as they increase in weight.
column3: The cones are from four to eight inches long, smooth, slender, cylindrical and somewhat curved. They grow in clusters of from three to six or seven and become pendulous as they increase in weight.

column2: This species is nearly related to the sugar pine and, though not half so tall, it suggests its noble relative in the way that it extends its long branches in general habit.
column3: This species is nearly related to the sugar pine and, though not half so tall, it suggests its noble relative in the way that it extends its long branches in general habit.

column2: It is first met on the upper margin of the silver fir zone, singly, in what appears as chance situations without making much impression on the general forest. Continuing up through the forests of the two-leaved pine it begins to show its distinguishing characteristic in the most marked way at an elevation of about 10,000 feet extending its tough, rather slender arms in the frosty air, welcoming the storms and feeding on them and reaching sometimes to the grand old age of 1000 years.
column3: It is first met on the upper margin of the silver fir zone, singly, in what appears as chance situations without making much impression on the general forest. Continuing up through the forests of the two leaved pine it begins to show its distinguishing characteristic in the most marked way at an elevation of about ten thousand feet extending its tough, rather slender arms in the frosty air, welcoming the storms and feeding on them and reaching sometimes to the grand old age of one thousand years.

column2: The Western Juniper
column3: The Western Juniper

column2: The Juniper or Red Cedar (Juniperus occidentalis) is preeminently a rock tree, occupying the baldest domes and pavements in the upper silver fir and alpine zones, at a height of from 7000 to 9500 feet.
column3: The Juniper or Red Cedar (Juniperus occidentalis) is preeminently a rock tree, occupying the baldest domes and pavements in the upper silver fir and alpine zones, at a height of from seven thousand to nine thousand five hundred feet.

column2: In such situations, rooted in narrow cracks or fissures, where there is scarcely a handful of soil, it is frequently over eight feet in diameter and not much more in height.
column3: In such situations, rooted in narrow cracks or fissures, where there is scarcely a handful of soil, it is frequently over eight feet in diameter and not much more in height.

column2: The tops of old trees are almost always dead, and large stubborn-looking limbs push out horizontally, most of them broken and dead at the end, but densely covered, and imbedded here and there with tufts or mounds of gray-green scalelike foliage.
column3: The tops of old trees are almost always dead, and large stubborn looking limbs push out horizontally, most of them broken and dead at the end, but densely covered, and imbedded here and there with tufts or mounds of gray green scalelike foliage.

column2: Some trees are mere storm-beaten stumps about as broad as long, decorated with a few leafy sprays, reminding one of the crumbling towers of old castles scantily draped with ivy.
column3: Some trees are mere storm beaten stumps about as broad as long, decorated with a few leafy sprays, reminding one of the crumbling towers of old castles scantily draped with ivy.

column2: Its homes on bare, barren dome and ridge-top seem to have been chosen for safety against fire, for, on isolated mounds of sand and gravel free from grass and bushes on which fire could feed, it is often found growing tall and unscathed to a height of forty to sixty feet, with scarce a trace of the rocky angularity and broken limbs so characteristic a feature throughout the greater part of its range.
column3: Its homes on bare, barren dome and ridge top seem to have been chosen for safety against fire, for, on isolated mounds of sand and gravel free from grass and bushes on which fire could feed, it is often found growing tall and unscathed to a height of forty to sixty feet, with scarce a trace of the rocky angularity and broken limbs so characteristic a feature throughout the greater part of its range.

column2: It never makes anything like a forest; seldom even a grove. Usually it stands out separate and independent, clinging by slight joints to the rocks, living chiefly on snow and thin air and maintaining sound health on this diet for 2000 years or more.
column3: It never makes anything like a forest; seldom even a grove. Usually it stands out separate and independent, clinging by slight joints to the rocks, living chiefly on snow and thin air and maintaining sound health on this diet for two thousand years or more.

column2: Every feature or every gesture it makes expresses steadfast, dogged endurance.
column3: Every feature or every gesture it makes expresses steadfast, dogged endurance.

column2: The bark is of a bright cinnamon color and is handsomely braided and reticulated on thrifty trees, flaking off in thin, shining ribbons that are sometimes used by the Indians for tent matting.
column3: The bark is of a bright cinnamon color and is handsomely braided and reticulated on thrifty trees, flaking off in thin, shining ribbons that are sometimes used by the Indians for tent matting.

column2: Its fine color and picturesqueness are appreciated by artists, but to me the juniper seems a singularly strange and taciturn tree.
column3: Its fine color and picturesqueness are appreciated by artists, but to me the juniper seems a singularly strange and taciturn tree.

column2: I have spent many a day and night in its company and always have found it silent and rigid.
column3: I have spent many a day and night in its company and always have found it silent and rigid.

column2: It seems to be a survivor of some ancient race, wholly unacquainted with its neighbors. Its broad stumpiness, of course, makes wind-waving or even shaking out of the question, but it is not this rocky rigidity that constitutes its silence.
column3: It seems to be a survivor of some ancient race, wholly unacquainted with its neighbors. Its broad stumpiness, of course, makes wind waving or even shaking out of the question, but it is not this rocky rigidity that constitutes its silence.

column2: In calm, sun-days the sugar pine preaches like an enthusiastic apostle without moving a leaf.
column3: In calm, sun days the sugar pine preaches like an enthusiastic apostle without moving a leaf.

column2: On level rocks the juniper dies standing and wastes insensibly out of existence like granite, the wind exerting about as little control over it, alive or dead, as is does over a glacier boulder.
column3: On level rocks the juniper dies standing and wastes insensibly out of existence like granite, the wind exerting about as little control over it, alive or dead, as is does over a glacier boulder.

column2: I have spent a good deal of time trying to determine the age of these wonderful trees, but as all of the very old ones are honey-combed with dry rot I never was able to get a complete count of the largest.
column3: I have spent a good deal of time trying to determine the age of these wonderful trees, but as all of the very old ones are honey combed with dry rot I never was able to get a complete count of the largest.

column2: Some are undoubtedly more than 2000 years old, for though on deep moraine soil they grow about as fast as some of the pines, on bare pavements and smoothly glaciated, overswept ridges in the dome region they grow very slowly.
column3: Some are undoubtedly more than two thousand years old, for though on deep moraine soil they grow about as fast as some of the pines, on bare pavements and smoothly glaciated, overswept ridges in the dome region they grow very slowly.

column2: One on the Starr King Ridge only two feet eleven inches in diameter was 1140 years old forty years ago.
column3: One on the Starr King Ridge only two feet eleven inches in diameter was one thousand one hundred forty years old forty years ago.

column2: Another on the same ridge, only one foot seven and a half inches in diameter, had reached the age of 834 years.
column3: Another on the same ridge, only one foot seven and a half inches in diameter, had reached the age of eight hundred thirty four years.

column2: The first fifteen inches from the bark of a medium-size tree six feet in diameter, on the north Tenaya pavement, had 859 layers of wood.
column3: The first fifteen inches from the bark of a medium size tree six feet in diameter, on the north Tenaya pavement, had eight hundred fifty nine layers of wood.

column2: Beyond this the count was stopped by dry rot and scars.
column3: Beyond this the count was stopped by dry rot and scars.

column2: The largest examined was thirty-three feet in girth, or nearly ten feet in diameter and, although I have failed to get anything like a complete count, I learned enough from this and many other specimens to convince me that most of the trees eight or ten feet thick, standing on pavements, are more than twenty centuries old rather than less.
column3: The largest examined was thirty three feet in girth, or nearly ten feet in diameter and, although I have failed to get anything like a complete count, I learned enough from this and many other specimens to convince me that most of the trees eight or ten feet thick, standing on pavements, are more than twenty centuries old rather than less.

column2: Barring accidents, for all I can see they would live forever; even then overthrown by avalanches, they refuse to lie at rest, lean stubbornly on their big branches as if anxious to rise, and while a single root holds to the rock, put forth fresh leaves with a grim, never-say-die expression.
column3: Barring accidents, for all I can see they would live forever; even then overthrown by avalanches, they refuse to lie at rest, lean stubbornly on their big branches as if anxious to rise, and while a single root holds to the rock, put forth fresh leaves with a grim, never say die expression.

column2: The Mountain Hemlock
column3: The Mountain Hemlock

column2: As the juniper is the most stubborn and unshakeable of trees in the Yosemite region, the Mountain Hemlock (Tsuga Mertensiana) is the most graceful and pliant and sensitive.
column3: As the juniper is the most stubborn and unshakeable of trees in the Yosemite region, the Mountain Hemlock (Tsuga Mertensiana) is the most graceful and pliant and sensitive.

column2: Until it reaches a height of fifty or sixty feet it is sumptuously clothed down to the ground with drooping branches, which are divided again and again into delicate waving sprays, grouped and arranged in ways that are indescribably beautiful, and profusely adorned with small brown cones.
column3: Until it reaches a height of fifty or sixty feet it is sumptuously clothed down to the ground with drooping branches, which are divided again and again into delicate waving sprays, grouped and arranged in ways that are indescribably beautiful, and profusely adorned with small brown cones.

column2: The flowers also are peculiarly beautiful and effective; the female dark rich purple, the male blue, of so fine and pure a tone.
column3: The flowers also are peculiarly beautiful and effective; the female dark rich purple, the male blue, of so fine and pure a tone.

column2: What the best azure of the mountain sky seems to be condensed in them.
column3: What the best azure of the mountain sky seems to be condensed in them.

column2: Though apparently the most delicate and feminine of all the mountain trees, it grows best where the snow lies deepest, at a height of from 9000 to 9500 feet, in hollows on the northern slopes of mountains and ridges.
column3: Though apparently the most delicate and feminine of all the mountain trees, it grows best where the snow lies deepest, at a height of from nine thousand to nine thousand five hundred feet, in hollows on the northern slopes of mountains and ridges.

column2: But under all circumstances, sheltered from heavy winds or in bleak exposure to them, well fed or starved, even at its highest limit, 10,500 feet above the sea, on exposed ridge-tops where it has to crouch and huddle close in low thickets, it still contrives to put forth its sprays and branches in forms of invincible beauty, while on moist, well-drained moraines it displays a perfectly tropical luxuriance of foliage, flowers and fruit. The snow of the first winter storm is frequently soft, and lodges in due dense leafy branches, weighing them down against the trunk, and the slender, drooping axis, bending lower and lower as the load increases, at length reaches the ground, forming an ornamental arch.
column3: But under all circumstances, sheltered from heavy winds or in bleak exposure to them, well fed or starved, even at its highest limit, ten thousand five hundred feet above the sea, on exposed ridge tops where it has to crouch and huddle close in low thickets, it still contrives to put forth its sprays and branches in forms of invincible beauty, while on moist, well drained moraines it displays a perfectly tropical luxuriance of foliage, flowers and fruit. The snow of the first winter storm is frequently soft, and lodges in due dense leafy branches, weighing them down against the trunk, and the slender, drooping axis, bending lower and lower as the load increases, at length reaches the ground, forming an ornamental arch.

column2: Then, as storm succeeds storm and snow is heaped on snow, the whole tree is at last buried, not again to see the light of day or move leaf or limb until set free by the spring thaws in June or July.
column3: Then, as storm succeeds storm and snow is heaped on snow, the whole tree is at last buried, not again to see the light of day or move leaf or limb until set free by the spring thaws in June or July.

column2: Not only the young saplings are thus carefully covered and put to sleep in the whitest of white beds for five or six months of the year, but trees thirty feet high or more. From April to May, when the snow by repeated thawing and freezing is firmly compacted, you may ride over the prostrate groves without seeing a single branch or leaf of them.
column3: Not only the young saplings are thus carefully covered and put to sleep in the whitest of white beds for five or six months of the year, but trees thirty feet high or more. From April to May, when the snow by repeated thawing and freezing is firmly compacted, you may ride over the prostrate groves without seeing a single branch or leaf of them.

column2: No other of our alpine conifers so finely veils its strength; poised in thin, white sunshine, clad with branches from head to foot, it towers in unassuming majesty, drooping as if unaffected with the aspiring tendencies of its race, loving the ground, conscious of heaven and joyously receptive of its blessings, reaching out its branches like sensitive tentacles, feeling the light and reveling in it.
column3: No other of our alpine conifers so finely veils its strength; poised in thin, white sunshine, clad with branches from head to foot, it towers in unassuming majesty, drooping as if unaffected with the aspiring tendencies of its race, loving the ground, conscious of heaven and joyously receptive of its blessings, reaching out its branches like sensitive tentacles, feeling the light and reveling in it.

column2: The largest specimen I ever found was nineteen feet seven inches in circumference.
column3: The largest specimen I ever found was nineteen feet seven inches in circumference.

column2: It was growing on the edge of Lake Hollow, north of Mount Hoffman, at an elevation of 9250 feet above the level of the sea, and was probably about a hundred feet in height.
column3: It was growing on the edge of Lake Hollow, north of Mount Hoffman, at an elevation of nine thousand two hundred fifty feet above the level of the sea, and was probably about a hundred feet in height.

column2: Fine groves of mature trees, ninety to a hundred feet in height, are growing near the base of Mount Conness.
column3: Fine groves of mature trees, ninety to a hundred feet in height, are growing near the base of Mount Conness.

column2: It is widely distributed from near the south extremity of the high Sierra northward along the Cascade Mountains of Oregon and Washington and the coast ranges of British Columbia to Alaska, where it was first discovered in 1827.
column3: It is widely distributed from near the south extremity of the high Sierra northward along the Cascade Mountains of Oregon and Washington and the coast ranges of British Columbia to Alaska, where it was first discovered in eighteen twenty seven.

column2: Its northernmost limit, so far as I have observed, is in the icy fiords of Prince William Sound in latitude 61 degrees, where it forms pure forests at the level of the sea, growing tall and majestic on the banks of glaciers.
column3: Its northernmost limit, so far as I have observed, is in the icy fiords of Prince William Sound in latitude sixty one degrees, where it forms pure forests at the level of the sea, growing tall and majestic on the banks of glaciers.

column2: There, as in the Yosemite region, it is ineffably beautiful, the very loveliest of all the American conifers.
column3: There, as in the Yosemite region, it is ineffably beautiful, the very loveliest of all the American conifers.
